title: A survey into the experience of musically induced chills: Emotions, situations and music
aims_questions: Develop a general understanding of chills in terms of emotional and physiological qualities, listening situations, and musical elicitors of the experience.
methods: Self-report survey. N=375 (186 F, 183 M, 6 other). 206 reported not playing instruments
results: Chills elicited when the music and words are relatable. Empathy for performer or character. Build ups, climaxes, chords. Clearest trend is the human voice being an elicitor of chills.
discussion: The human voice was frequently noted by participants, alongside emotional expressions perceived in the music. Further features associated with chills included crescendos, swells and climaxes, linked to increases in emotional arousal that may be conducive to chills. Chills associated with perceived interactions in the music among performers, instruments, or characters. Feeling of being moved.

title: Aesthetic Judgments of Music: Reliability, Consistency, Criteria, Self-Insight, and Expertise
aims_questions: To what extent are music listeners’ aesthetic judgments reliable? Are their judgments internally consistent? What criteria foraesthetic value do listeners rely on in their judgment policies? What level of self-insight do judges have with respect to theirjudgment policies? How are measures of (1) reliability, (2)consistency (3) number of criteria used and (4) self-insight relatedto a listener’s musical expertise?  (The aim was not to measure mu-sical taste but to investigate cognitive aspects of the judgmentprocess.) Hypotheses listed in paper on page 6.
methods: n=74 (34F, 39M, 1Other). Background questionaire (e.g., age, gender,nationality, education, musical interest, experience of playing mu-sical instruments, music education, prevalence of active music lis-tening, musical preferences, personality traits). Following, participants, judged 50 excerpts of music on 11 rating scales. 10 same as questionnaire (The criteria included beauty, groove, originality,complexity, expression, emotion, sound, prototypicality, message,and skill.), 1 overall aesthetic.
results: Listener interreliability was low, while intrareliability was high. Aesthetic judgements were highly consistent. Listeners relied on only a few aesthetic criteria for judgements. Low level of insight into personal judgement strategies. Failed to obtain clear support for hypothesisthat musical expertise, as indexed by music education, the playingof musical instruments, and frequency of active music listening,would be positively correlated with judge reliability, consistency,and self-insight.
discussion: Findings challenge other findings in the field. They suggestthat the large individual differences in judgment are not caused bylow internal consistency. Rather individual differences can be explained by weighting of criteria. An important new finding of the present study was that mostof the listeners showed a limited self-insight regarding their ownjudgment strategies. Perhaps the most surprising finding—even for the authors—was thegeneral absence of effects of musical expertise on aesthetic judgments. Overall, listeners with musical expertise did not display significantlyhigher interrater reliability, greater consistency or more insight con-cerning their own judgment strategies.

methods: Study 1: 9 stimuli each with 3 different performance qualities (plain, semi-professional, professional). Mixed within/between. Condition 1: plain and semiprofessional (n=70). results: Both studies: Higher performance quality led to higher liking and higher intensity emotions. Musical experience amplified the performance effect (ie a more musically experienced participant --> higher emotional intensity and liking.)
discussion: Care should be taken when using MIDI files, royalty free databases which include amateur recordings, other art forms may follow the same patterns (I would definitely hypothesize that they do).

title: Mad and glad: Musically induced emotions have divergent impact on morals
Measuring music-induced emotion: A comparison of emotion models, personality biases, and intensity of experiences
aims_questions: The first aim of the present study was to compare the applicability of three different emotionmodels – the discrete emotion model, the three-dimensional model, and the GEMS – in the measurement of music-induced emotions. The second aim was to explore the role of personalityand mood in emotional responses to music, with regard to the musical excerpts and the emotion model used. Finally, the third aim was to investigate how the descriptive labels provided bythe different emotion models relate to the intensity of experienced emotions.
results: The dimensional model outperformed the GEMS and the discrete  emotion model in the discrimination of music excerpts, illustrating that the  simplest model may often be the most efficient one.
discussion: In summary, although the GEMS may provide more nuanced information about musically induced emotions (especially in  situations where strong, aesthetic emotions are experienced), the dimensional model appears to be the most  efficient and reliable way of collecting and representing musical emotion data.

Music-induced emotions influence intertemporal decision making
aims_questions: Examine the impacts of music-induced incidental emotion of intertemporal decision making.
discussion: The main contribution of this research is to show the real-time impact of music-induced incidental emotions on the discount factors of intertemporal decision making. Consistent with previous studies examining the eﬀects of viewing aﬀective pictures on intertemporal decision making (e.g. Sohn et al., 2015), this study reveals that high arousal induced by music makes people impatient when making intertemporal choices. The study also suggests that music can be an eﬀective intervenient variable over intertemporal choices and thus can create a new form of emotional  intervention in choice architecture to nudge people toward improved decisions by organising the context in which people make decision.

title: Scoping Review on the Use of Music for Emotion Regulation
aims_questions: The purpose of this study was to examine the concepts on the  regulatory impact of music on emotion using a scoping review procedure.
results: The results showed that there were some definitional  challenges in each component of music emotion regulation. Most studies treated  music as a single variable without exploring the regulatory mechanism of the intra-musical  elements that constitute music. When examining the regulatory impact of music on emotion,  emotion was inclusive of other terms ranging from feeling to mood. Most of the MER studies employed the  terms used in the emotion regulation strategies; however, there were some regulatory processes  that pertained solely to music’s cathartic effect.
discussion: Overall, the results showed that music emotion regulation  (MER) was not clearly distinguished from music emotion (ME) studies. Future research should  allocate more attention to the theoretical mechanism behind music’s intrinsic regulatory effect in  emotion regulation (MER) studies.
